questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with elevated cholesterol levels and a history of alcohol abuse. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and there are signs of impaired detoxification. Upon further investigation, it is suspected that the patient's liver cells are not effectively metabolizing lipids. Which organelle's dysfunction might be contributing to the patient's lipid metabolism issues and compromised detoxification capabilities?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum

 

Option C: Correct. The Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum (SER) is involved in lipid metabolism, including the synthesis of cholesterol and phospholipids, and detoxification of drugs and alcohol. Dysfunction of the SER would compromise these processes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Mitochondria are responsible for energy production and play a role in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, but their dysfunction is less likely to be directly responsible for impaired lipid metabolism and detoxification compared to the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option B. Incorrect. The Golgi apparatus is involved in modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids for secretion or use within the cell; it is not primarily involved in lipid metabolism or detoxification processes.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Lysosomes are involved in the breakdown of cellular waste and apoptosis. While they do play a role in lipid digestion through hydrolytic enzymes, they are not the main site for lipid metabolism or detoxification

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comprehensively understand the structure and function of essential cell organelles such as the nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, mitochondria, lysosomes, and others, enabling doctors to correlate organelle dysfunction with clinical manifestations, thereby enhancing diagnostic accuracy and treatment strategies for various cellular and systemic disorders.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 43

questions.text: In an enzyme kinetics experiment, a substrate concentration 1000 times the Km value resulted in the conversion of 1% of the substrate into 12 µmol of product in 9 minutes with a certain enzyme amount. In a modified experiment, one-third of the initial enzyme amount is used with double the initial substrate concentration. How long would it take to produce the same amount (12 µmol) of product in the modified experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 27 minutes

 Option A.                                                              

  • Zero-Order Reactions. In some reactions, the rate is apparently independent of the substrate concentration. The rates of these zero-order reactions do not vary with increasing nor decreasing substrate concentrations.
  • First-order reaction. : the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the substrate
  • Km : Substrate concentration at which the velocity is half maximum
  • Usually reactions follow zero order Kinetics if substrate concentration is > 10 times of Km value. Here substrate concentration is 1000Km which means irrespective of increasing substrate concentration the reaction won’t be affected.
  • First experiment mentions that 12 µmol products are formed in 9 minutes.
  • In the second experiment the enzyme concentration is reduced to 1/3rd. so the time taken to form the same amount of product will be tripled. Thus the answer is 27 minutes

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reaction rate at or near Vmax is less affected by substrate concentration and more by enzyme concentration. Reducing enzyme to one-third decreases the rate to one-third, extending production time for 12 µmol of product to 27 minutes.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 76-79.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient undergoing a routine physical examination presents with a blood pressure of 132/82 mm Hg, a heart rate of 74 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. His cardiac output is measured at 4.8 L/min. Given these parameters, the clinician aims to calculate the patient's stroke volume to assess cardiac function further. What is the stroke volume in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 65 mL

 

Explanation:

 

Option D:

 

65 mL is the correct answer.

 

  • The stroke volume is defined as the volume of blood pumped out from the ventricles during each heartbeat (each cardiac cycle)

 

The stroke volume calculated using the formula.

 

 

Here, cardiac output = 4.8 L = 4800 mL, heart rate = 74/min

 

Stroke volume = 4800 / 74 = 64.86 mL  =  65 mL

 

Educational Objective:

 

Learn how to calculate stroke volume using the cardiac output and heart rate, understanding its significance in evaluating cardiac function and ventricular efficiency in clinical practice.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 544

choices.text: The spleen is situated in the Upper Left Quadrant of the Abdomen beneath the Diaphragm.
The Long Axis of the Spleen lies along the 10th Rib
A pathologically enlarged Spleen extends downward and forward, toward the Left Iliac Fossa.
The Spleen has a notched Anterosuperior Border caused by Incomplete Fusion of its parts during Development.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was admitted for a large swelling which was found to extend downward and medially below the left costal margin. On percussion, a continuous band of dullness was noted to extend upward from the left of the umbilicus to the left axillary region. On palpation, a notch was felt along the anterior border of the swelling. A diagnosis of splenic enlargement was made. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A pathologically enlarged Spleen extends downward and forward, toward the Left Iliac Fossa.

 

Option C: This statement is incorrect.

 

  • The spleen is situated mainly in the left hypochondrium and partly in the epigastrium between the fundus of stomach and diaphragm.

 

 

 

  • The long axis of the spleen is oblique directed downwards, forwards and laterally and lies along the 10th rib.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The spleen is located in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen, just beneath the diaphragm. It's positioned between the 9th and 11th ribs, tucked under the ribcage, which offers it some protection.

 

 

Option B. The long axis of the spleen is indeed oriented along the line of the 10th rib on the left side. It typically extends from the 9th to the 11th rib, paralleling the curvature of the 10th rib.

 

 

 

Option D. While it is true that the spleen have a notched superior or anterosuperior border, this is a normal anatomical feature and not related to pathological conditions. The notches on the spleen are due to the incomplete fusion of the splenic lobules during development.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In cases of splenic enlargement, the spleen can extend beyond its usual boundaries in the abdomen.

  • Because of the presence of the left colic flexure and the phrenicocolic ligament, the spleen is unable to expand vertically downward hence it extends downward and forward, toward the right iliac fossa.

 

Ref: Grayâ€™s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg no. 1188

choices.text: Femoral Pulse Normal in Both Limbs
The Popliteal, Posterior Tibial, and Dorsalis Pedis pulses were present in the Right Leg and completely absent in the Left Leg
Arteriography revealed a Blockage of the Left Femoral Artery at the level of the Adductor Tubercle
The Perforating Branches of the Profunda Femoris Artery did not participate in the Collateral Circulation around the Blocked Femoral Artery

questions.text: A 67-year-old female told her physician that she could walk only 60 yards per day, following which she developed a cramp like pain, fatigue, heaviness in her left side lower thigh and calf. Unable to continue her walk, she was forced to rest. After a thorough physical examination, a diagnosis of severe intermittent claudication of the left lower limb was made. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Perforating Branches of the Profunda Femoris Artery did not participate in the Collateral Circulation around the Blocked Femoral Artery

 

Option D: This statement represents the incorrect statement among the options.

 

  • The case describes a 67-year-old female with severe intermittent claudication in her left lower limb. Intermittent claudication refers to pain and cramping in the lower leg due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles, typically a symptom of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD).
  • Arterial supply of lower limb is shown in below image:

 

 

  • The profunda femoris artery arises from the femoral artery about 1.5 in. below the inguinal ligament. It plays a major role in the formation of the collateral circulation around the knee joint.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. In cases of intermittent claudication, the femoral pulse may still be palpable if the blockage is distal to the site where the pulse is assessed. The presence of a normal femoral pulse does not exclude the possibility of arterial blockages in more distal areas of the leg.

 

Option B. The absence of pulses in the popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries in the left leg suggests a significant obstruction in the arterial supply to this limb, while their presence in the right leg indicates normal blood flow there.

 

Option C. A blockage in the left femoral artery at the level of the adductor tubercle could lead to reduced blood flow to the left lower limb, resulting in pain and cramping due to intermittent claudication.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of arterial blockage, collateral circulation often develops to bypass the obstruction. The profunda femoris artery, particularly its perforating branches, plays a crucial role in forming collateral circulation around a blocked femoral artery. These branches provide alternative pathways for blood flow, potentially reducing the severity of symptoms.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1367

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes, known for its critical role in both anaerobic and aerobic pathways by interconverting a three-carbon compound with its reduced form, contains the Rossmann fold associated NADH domain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lactate Dehydrogenase    

 

Option D.

 

Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme that catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate, with the concomitant interconversion of NADH and NAD+, in both anaerobic and aerobic pathways. It is known to contain the Rossmann fold, a structural motif essential for NADH binding. This motif facilitates the enzyme's critical role in energy metabolism, especially under anaerobic conditions, such as during intense exercise when oxygen is scarce, and cells rely more on glycolysis for ATP production.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase: It is a multi-enzyme complex with 5 coenzymes and 3 apo-enzymes, which favours oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl CoA.

 

Option B. Isocitrate Dehydrogenase: It is a NAD linked dehydrogenase, which helps in dehydrogenation and decarboxylation of isocitrate to alpha ketoglutarate.

 

Option C. ALA dehydratase: Involved in heme synthesis.

 

OXIDOREDUCTASE GROUP OF ENZYMES WITH ROSSMAN FOLD

 

  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Malate dehydrogenase
  • Quinone oxidoreductase
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • D-glycerate dehydrogenase
  • Formate dehydrogenase

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 40.

choices.text: Substrate concentration at maximum velocity
Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
Not a characteristic feature of enzymes
A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Michaelis constant (Km)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity

 

Option B.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km) is defined as the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of its maximum value (Vmax). It is a fundamental parameter in enzyme kinetics that provides insight into the enzyme's affinity for its substrate; a lower Km value indicates a higher affinity because less substrate is needed to reach half-maximal velocity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity: This statement is incorrect. The substrate concentration at maximum velocity is not specifically defined by Km, as Vmax is reached at much higher substrate concentrations where all enzyme active sites are saturated.

Option C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes: This statement is incorrect. Km is indeed a characteristic feature of enzymes and is crucial in the study of enzyme kinetics.

 

Option D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation: This statement is incorrect. A low Km value actually indicates a high affinity of the enzyme for its substrate, as it means the enzyme can achieve half-maximal velocity at a lower substrate concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salient features of Km:

 

  1. Km value is substrate concentration (expressed in moles/L) at half-maximal velocity.
  2. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration.
  3. It is independent of enzyme concentration.
  4. It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate.
  5. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely connected to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex.
  6. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates. So, less the numerical value of Km, the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate is more.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 57.

choices.text: Superficial Cervical Nodes

questions.text: Where does the pointed structure drain into?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submandibular Nodes

 

Option D: The pointed structure is the frontal sinus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Retro auricular nodes/Mastoid nodes drain part of auricle, scalp and posterior wall of External Acoustic Meatus.

 

Option B: Preauricular lymph nodes belong to superficial group of parotid nodes and lie in front of tragus.

 

Option C: Superficial cervical nodes receive lymph from the floor of external acoustic meatus, lobule of ear, angle of mandible and lower part of parotid region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frontal sinus, most of the ethmoidal sinus and maxillary sinus drain into submandibular lymph nodes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 221

questions.text: Which enzymatic reaction, crucial in amino acid metabolism, requires the involvement of PLP as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transamination

 

Option A.

 

Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP) is the active form of vitamin B6 and serves as a vital coenzyme in amino acid metabolism. It is specifically required for transamination reactions, where it facilitates the transfer of an amino group from an amino acid to an alpha-keto acid. This process is fundamental in the synthesis of non-essential amino acids and the metabolism of nitrogen-containing compounds, which is essential for maintaining the amino acid balance in the body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dehydrogenation: Dehydrogenation reactions, which involve the removal of hydrogen atoms to form a double bond within a molecule, commonly utilize NAD+ or NADP+ as coenzymes, not PLP. These reactions are central to various metabolic pathways, including glycolysis and the citric acid cycle.

 

Option C. Carboxylation: Carboxylation involves the addition of a carboxyl group to a substrate and typically requires biotin as a coenzyme, not PLP. This reaction is crucial in processes such as fatty acid synthesis and the metabolism of certain amino acids.

 

Option D. Oxidative decarboxylation: This reaction, which involves the removal of a carboxyl group and the simultaneous oxidation of the molecule, frequently depends on thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a coenzyme. Key metabolic pathways, including the transition from glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, involve oxidative decarboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transamination reactions are catalysed by aminotransferases /transaminases which need PLP as the co-enzyme.

 

Alanine + Alpha ketoglutarate ---------------→ Pyruvate + Glutamic acid

                                                  (En: Alanine transaminase)

 

Also, in metabolism of sulfur containing amino acids. Plays an important role in methionine and cysteine metabolism.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 201, 483.

choices.text: V1 receptor - responsible for the modulation of vascular tone and peripheral vasoconstriction.
V 2 receptor - primarily located in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts of the kidneys, facilitating water reabsorption.
V3 receptor - found in the anterior pituitary, regulating the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) in response to stress.
V4 receptor - predominantly situated in the central nervous system (CNS), facilitating water reabsorption.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient admitted with polyuria, polydipsia, and persistent hypotension following a traumatic brain injury, which receptors proposed function does Not accurately align with its physiological role in this patient's clinical presentation post-traumatic brain injury and associated symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, and hypotension?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) V4 receptor - predominantly situated in the central nervous system (CNS), facilitating water reabsorption.

 

Option D. V4 Receptor: There isn't a known V4 receptor related to water reabsorption in the CNS, so its proposed function doesn't align with the patient's clinical presentation, making it the inaccurate option.

 

There are only V1 (V1A), V2 and V3 (V1B) receptors in our body. V4 receptors are not seen.

 

The three types of receptors seen for the vasopressin in our body are

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. V1 Receptor: Responsible for vasoconstriction and modulation of vascular tone; its role aligns with symptoms like hypotension following a brain injury, possibly due to impaired vasoconstriction.

 

Option B. V2 Receptor: Located in kidneys, it regulates water reabsorption; dysfunction could lead to polyuria and polydipsia, matching the patient's symptoms post-injury.

 

Option C. V3 Receptor: Found in the anterior pituitary, it regulates ACTH release; its role in stress response aligns with the patient's condition following traumatic brain injury.


Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the roles of vasopressin receptors (V1, V2, V3, V4) aids in understanding their physiological functions. In the context of a traumatic brain injury the proposed function of the V4 receptor, related to CNS activities like memory consolidation, does not correlate with the symptoms, unlike the roles of V1, V2, and V3 receptors in vascular regulation, kidney water reabsorption, and stress response, respectively.

 

Ref:  Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page Number: 666

choices.text: The Palms of the Hands are facing Posteriorly.
The Feet are dorsiflexed at the ankles.

questions.text: Concept of â€œAnatomical Positionâ€ is very essential for all kind of operative procedure and to understand and publish the articles.  About anatomical position, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) The Thumbs are oriented Laterally.

 

This question is about the basic anatomical position of the human body.

 

Option B. The thumbs are indeed oriented laterally. This is a defining characteristic of the anatomical position, and it helps provide consistency in anatomical descriptions.

 

  • The anatomical position is a standardized reference posture used in anatomical and all medical & surgical descriptions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The palms of the hands are facing anteriorly, not posteriorly. This allows for a clear view of the anatomical structures of the body.

 

Option C. The feet are not dorsiflexed at the ankles in the anatomical position. Instead, they are in a neutral position, with the toes pointing forward.

 

Option D. The elbows are not fully flexed; they are extended in the anatomical position but not fully. This extension allows for accurate descriptions of the upper limbâ€™s anatomical relationships.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the anatomical position, the thumbs are oriented laterally. This position serves as a standardized reference for describing the location and orientation of anatomical structures in the human body.

 

Ref: BD Chaurasiaâ€™s Handbook of General Anatomy, 7th edition, Page no- 11, 12

choices.text: It forms the half of the potion of enzyme
It binds with substrate by non-covalent bonds
It is not usually a cleft or crevices
Binding of substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a key aspect of the active site of an enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It binds with substrate by non-covalent bonds

 

Option B.

 

The active site of an enzyme is the region where substrate molecules bind and undergo a chemical reaction. This binding is typically achieved through non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, van der Waals forces, and hydrophobic interactions. These interactions ensure that the substrate is precisely aligned in the active site, facilitating the catalytic process while allowing for the substrate's release after the reaction.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It forms half of the portion of the enzyme: This statement is inaccurate. The active site usually comprises only a small portion of the enzyme's total volume, specifically tailored for substrate binding and catalysis.

 

Option C. It is not usually a cleft or crevice: Contrary to this statement, the active site is often a cleft or crevice on the enzyme's surface. This structural feature allows the active site to accommodate the substrate molecule(s) and exclude water, which is crucial for many enzymatic reactions.

 

Option D. Binding of the substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups: This statement is incorrect. The binding of the substrate to the active site is highly dependent on the precise alignment and orientation of specific amino acid residues and functional groups within the active site. This specificity ensures that only particular substrates can bind and be catalytically transformed by the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. The region of the enzyme where substrate binding and catalysis takes place is known as active site or active centre and it contains substrate binding site and catalytic site.
  2. Though all parts are required for maintaining the three-dimensional structure of the enzyme, the reaction is taking place at the active site and it occupies only a small portion of the whole enzyme.
  3. Active site is situated in a crevice or cleft of the enzyme molecule.
  4. To the active site, substrate is bound and the binding depends on the alignment of specific groups or atoms at active site and these groups realign themselves to provide the unique conformational orientation so as to promote exact fitting of substrate to the active site.
  5. The substrate binds to the enzyme at the active site by noncovalent bonds and are hydrophobic in nature.
  6. The amino acids or groups which directly participate in making or breaking the bonds (present at the active site) are known as catalytic residues or catalytic groups.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 55.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with palpitations and occasional dizziness. She denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. Her family history is significant for sudden cardiac death in her brother at the age of 50. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and an ECG shows episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia. An echocardiogram reveals mild right ventricular dilation with preserved ejection fraction. The patient's condition is related to abnormality of following cell junctions at marked area except.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zona Occludens


Option B:
 

  • The given slide is cardiac muscle and the marked structure is intercalated disc.

  • Intercalated discs are specialized structures found in cardiac muscle cells (cardiomyocytes) An intercalated disc is responsible for transmission of electrical impulse from one cell to another.

  • Intercalated disc is made up of three types of cell junctions.
     

  1. Fascia adherens

  2. Gap junctions

  3. Desmosomes

 

The question is about except - i.e., intercalated disc is not made up of the Zona occludens.
 






 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a possible diagnosis of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC), a condition often associated with genetic mutations affecting the desmosomes in the cardiac intercalated discs.

  • Desmosomes are crucial for cell-to-cell adhesion in cardiac muscle and abnormalities can lead to myocardial cell detachment and fibro-fatty replacement, particularly in the right ventricle, predisposing to arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death.

  • The other options (Gap junctions, Zona occludens, Fascia adherens) are also components of intercalated discs, but desmosomal abnormalities are most consistent with this clinical presentation and family history.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Gap Junctions are a key component of intercalated discs. Gap junctions allow for direct cytoplasmic connections between adjacent cardiac muscle cells. It enables the rapid and coordinated spread of electrical impulses across the cardiac muscle. This synchronized contraction is essential for effective heart pumping.

 

Option C. Fascia Adherens are ribbon like protein structure that connect and bind cardiac muscle cells. They are broad intercellular junctions that anchor actin filaments. They are found at the peripheral region of cellular attachment where actin filaments of the I-band insert and terminate. They form large portion of intercalated disc, the structure at which myofibrils terminate in cardiomyocytes.

 

Option D. Desmosomes is also known as macula adherens. Desmosomes are a type of junction in the intercalated discs that provide strong adhesive connections between cardiac muscle cells. They are critical for maintaining the structural integrity of the heart during its relentless pumping action. They are composed of dense plaques of protein attached to the cell membrane, linked to intermediate filaments within the cell, providing strong mechanical attachment between cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zona Occludens, also known as tight junctions, these are not a part of intercalated discs. Zona occludens are found in epithelial tissues and serve to prevent the passage of molecules and ions through the space between cells. They create a barrier and maintain cell polarity. The absence of tight junctions in intercalated discs allows for the free passage of ions and molecules necessary for cardiac muscle function.

 

Ref: Histology, Text and Atlas, Brijesh kumar Page No. 119

questions.text: â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹A 36-year-old male presents to clinic for a routine health check-up. He has no significant past medical history and leads an active lifestyle. During his respiratory examination, you note the following parameters: His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, tidal volume is measured at 400 mL, and dead space volume is estimated to be 150 mL. What is the patient's alveolar ventilation per minute?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4000 mL

 

Explanation:

 

Option C:

 

  • The alveolar ventilation per minute can be defined as the total volume of new air entering the alveoli in one minute.
  • The alveolar ventilation per minute can be expressed as
    • Alveolar ventilation per min = (Tidal volume - dead space) x rate of respiration
    • Here, tidal volume = 400 mL, respiratory rate = 16/min
    • Dead space volume = 150 mL
    • Alveolar ventilation/min = (400 - 150) x 16 = 250 x 16 = 4000 mL

 

#Extra edge: Types of Dead Spaces –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand and accurately calculate alveolar ventilation rates using patient respiratory parameters.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No: 34

questions.text: A 27-year-old biochemistry graduate student is presenting her findings on enzyme kinetics at a regional conference. She displays a Lineweaver-Burk plot as part of her presentation, highlighting the utility of this type of graph in determining enzyme kinetics constants. She points out the x-intercept and asks her audience to identify what this value corresponds to in terms of Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Which of the following is equal to the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1/Km

 

Option B.

 

The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal graph of the Michaelis-Menten equation. By plotting 1/V versus 1/[S], a straight line is obtained where the y-intercept is 1/Vmaxâ€‹ and the x-intercept is −1/Kmâ€‹. The negative reciprocal of the Michaelis constant (Km) is represented by the x-intercept because the Lineweaver-Burk plot linearizes the hyperbolic curve of the Michaelis-Menten equation, thus allowing for easier calculation of Vmaxâ€‹ and Km.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kmâ€‹: This is incorrect because Kmâ€‹ itself is not represented by the x-intercept; rather, its negative reciprocal is.

 

Option C. Kmâ€‹/Vmaxâ€‹: This option is incorrect. While both Kmâ€‹ and Vmaxâ€‹ are parameters of the Michaelis-Menten equation, the ratio Kmâ€‹/Vmaxâ€‹ is not represented by the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Option D. 1/Vmaxâ€‹: This is incorrect because the y-intercept represents 1/Vmaxâ€‹, not the x-intercept.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • With “Double Reciprocal Plot” sometimes it is difficult to achieve high substrate concentrations to reach the maximal velocity conditions.
  • So, ½ Vmax or Km is difficult to determine thus experimental data at lower concentrations is plotted as reciprocals a straight line is obtained when extrapolated to get the reciprocal of Km. This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation.
  • If we plot 1/v against 1/[S], it will give a straight-line graph. X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 57.

questions.text:
In the anatomical arrangement of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box, etc., what primarily forms the roof of these spaces?

 

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves and vessels
  4. Deep fascia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  • Intermuscular spaces, like the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box, have a characteristic anatomical arrangement.
  • The roof of these intermuscular space is formed layer by layer from following structures.
  1. Skin - In this layer hair & skin appendages are present.
  2. Superficial fascia - In this layer subcutaneous fat , cutaneous nerves and vessels are present.
  3. Deep fascia - It is a dense, fibrous connective tissue layer, loaded with collagen, that surrounds and separates muscle groups, providing structural support and defining the boundaries of these anatomical regions.

 

From superficial to deep the layers are present as follows

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia along with contents 
  3. Deep fascia
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary structures forming the roof of intermuscular spaces, such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box are skin, superficial fascia & deep fascia along with their contents. 

 

Reference: Grayâ€™s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, International Edition, Page no - 872

BD Chaurasiaâ€™s Human Anatomy, 9th Edition, Volume 1, Page no - 107, 108

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with difficulty in speaking and swallowing. He reports that these symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past six months. Physical examination reveals atrophy and weakness of the tongue muscles. There is no sensory loss, and other cranial nerve functions are intact. His past medical history is significant for a long-standing diagnosis of a neurodegenerative disorder. Which of the following is the embryological origin of the affected muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipital Myotomes
 

Option C:

 

  • Muscles of tongue except palatoglossus develops from occipital somites myotomes.

 

 

  • Mucosa of tongue is derived from endodermal lining of first, third and fourth pharyngeal arch
  • Anterior two-third of tongue -from endoderm of first pharyngeal arch-two lateral lingual swelling and midline tuberculum impar.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The ectoderm gives rise to the skin, nervous system, and certain parts of the orofacial region. However, it does not contribute to the development of tongue muscles. The ectoderm forms more superficial structures rather than the musculature.

 

Option B: While the branchial arches contribute significantly to the structures in the head and neck, including parts of the tongue, they are not the primary source of the tongue muscles. The arches primarily contribute to the formation of the bones, cartilage, and connective tissues in the face and neck.

 

Option D: Septum Transversum is an embryonic structure that primarily contributes to the formation of the central tendon of the diaphragm. It is not involved in the development of tongue muscles. The septum transversum is more closely related to the development of structures in the thoracic region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The intrinsic muscles of the tongue develop from the occipital myotomes, which are segments of paraxial mesoderm located in the occipital region of the embryo.
  • These myotomes give rise to the muscle precursors that migrate into the developing tongue, forming its musculature.

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition. Yogesh Sontakke Pg 121

questions.text: What is the velocity of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction at the substrate concentration equal to Km?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Half the Vmax          

 

Option D.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of the maximum velocity (Vmax). Therefore, at a substrate concentration equal to Km, the velocity (V) of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction is half of Vmax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Half the substrate concentration: This option is incorrect because Km is not a measure of velocity but rather a specific substrate concentration.

 

Option B. Same as Vmax: This is incorrect. Vmax is reached only when the enzyme is saturated with substrate, which occurs at a substrate concentration much higher than Km.

 

Option C. Quarter the Vmax: This is also incorrect. The definition of Km specifies that the velocity is half of Vmax, not a quarter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SALIENT FEATURES OF Km:

 

  1. Km value is substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
  2. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration
  3. Km is independent of enzyme concentration.
  4. Km is the signature of the enzyme.
  5. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely related to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex.
  6. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80-82.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the Michaelis-Menten equation accurately?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V = Vmax X [S] / Km + [S]

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The Michaelis-Menten equation describes the relationship between substrate concentration ([S]) and reaction velocity (Vi) for an enzyme-catalyzed reaction:

 

V= Vmax x S / Km + S

 

Where:

  • V = velocity of Reaction 
    • Vmax = Maximum reaction velocity
    • [S] = Substrate concentration
    • Km = Michaelis constant (substrate concentration at half Vmax)
  • This equation shows that the reaction velocity increases hyperbolically with increasing substrate concentration.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 79.

questions.text:
Which of the following are secreted from the parietal cells of the stomach?

 

  1. Mucous
  2. Hydrochloric acid
  3. Gastrin
  4. Intrinsic factor
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4 (Hydrochloric Acid and Intrinsic Factor)

 

Option B. Correct. Parietal cells in the stomach are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid, essential for digestion, and intrinsic factor, vital for vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Different Cells and their Secretions are the following:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While parietal cells secrete hydrochloric acid, which is crucial for stomach acidity and digestion, they also secrete another important component.

 

Option C. Gastrin is not secreted by parietal cells; it is secreted by G cells in the stomach lining.

 

Option D. Mucous and gastrin are not secreted by parietal cells. Mucous is secreted by mucous cells, and gastrin by G cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the specific roles of parietal cells in the stomach, particularly their secretion of hydrochloric acid for digestion and intrinsic factor for vitamin B12 absorption, distinguishing their functions from those of other stomach cell types.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no: 427

questions.text: Patient undergoing treatment for Borderline tuberculoid leprosy presented with papular lesion on (frontal & maxillary area) forehead, nose extending bilateral to cheeks with sensory involvement. Which nerve is involved:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trigeminal nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • Sensory innervation of face is from ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular division of trigeminal nerve, except the skin over the angle of mandible is from great auricular nerve, a branch from cervical plexus

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The Facial nerve, or seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), primarily controls the muscles of facial expression. It also provides some sensory function for the external ear and has parasympathetic fibers. While the Facial nerve does affect the facial region, its primary role is motor control rather than sensation. The patient's symptoms are more aligned with sensory involvement, which is less indicative of Facial nerve pathology.

 

Option C. The Transverse Cervical nerve arises from the cervical plexus, typically from the second and third cervical nerves. It provides sensation to the anterior neck. The distribution of the lesion in the patient does not align with the innervation territory of the Transverse Cervical nerve, which is focused on the neck area and not the face.

 

Option D. The Ventral ramus of the second cervical nerve (C2) forms part of the cervical plexus and contributes to the innervation of the neck. Similar to the Transverse Cervical nerve, the Ventral ramus of C2 is involved in innervating the neck area, not the facial regions described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Trigeminal nerve, also known as the fifth cranial nerve (CN V), is primarily responsible for sensation in the face. It has three branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) branches.

  •  The description of the lesions on the forehead, nose, and extending bilaterally to the cheeks correlates with the areas innervated by the Trigeminal nerve, specifically the ophthalmic and maxillary branches.

  • The sensory involvement further supports this, as the Trigeminal nerve is a key sensory nerve for the face.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg. 63

questions.text: â€œAs we Increase Temperature initially velocity of an enzymatic reaction increases after a particular temperature velocity of enzymatic reaction decreasesâ€. Is this statement true or false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. True

 

Option A:

 

The velocity of the reaction increases with increase in temperature â†’ peak velocity is reached â†’ Further elevation of the temperature â†’ decrease in reaction velocity as a result of temperature induced denaturation of the enzyme.

 

The optimum temperature for most human enzymes is between 35Â°C and 40Â°C, after which human enzymes start to denature.

 

But thermophilic bacteria found in the hot springs have optimum temperatures of 70Â°C.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Denaturation disrupts the enzyme's three-dimensional structure, essential for its catalytic activity, ultimately resulting in a decrease in reaction velocity.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 57

choices.text: Afferent Arteriolar Constriction, Efferent Arteriolar Dilation
Afferent Arteriolar Dilation, Efferent Arteriolar Constriction
Afferent Arteriolar Constriction, Efferent Arteriolar Constriction
Afferent Arteriolar Dilation, Efferent Arteriolar Dilation

questions.text: In assessing a patient's kidney function, understanding the factors that affect glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is crucial. Which of the following conditions will increase the glomerular filtration rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Afferent Arteriolar Dilation, Efferent Arteriolar Constriction

 

Option B: Correct. Afferent arteriolar dilation increases blood flow into the glomerulus, and efferent arteriolar constriction increases pressure within the glomerulus, thereby increasing GFR.

 

Afferent arteriolar dilation increases renal blood flow and GFR.

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction, ↑ hydrostatic pressure in the glomerulus and tends to increase GFR. Therefore, this combination is likely to increase GFR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Afferent arteriolar constriction and efferent arteriolar dilation would decrease GFR by reducing blood flow into the glomerulus and increasing outflow.

 

Option C. Both afferent and efferent arteriolar constriction would likely decrease GFR by reducing blood flow and pressure in the glomerulus.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Dilation of both arterioles could decrease the pressure in the glomerulus, thereby reducing GFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand how changes in the diameter of afferent and efferent arterioles affect glomerular filtration rate, which is critical in evaluating renal function and managing renal diseases.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page Number: 471

choices.text: A-1, B-4, C-5, D-6, E-3, F- 2
A-2, B-5, C-6 ,D-3, E-2, F-4
A-1, B-4, C-5, D-6, E-2, F-3
A-2, B-6, C-5, D-3, E-2, F-4

questions.text: Match the following structures with the appropriate cross-section level of brainstem?
questions.solution:
Ans:  A) A-1, B-4,C-5, D-6, E-3, F-2

 

Explanation :

 

  1. Medulla at the level of sensory decussation - Hypoglossal nucleus: Responsible for controlling the muscles of the tongue, is located in the medulla.

 

  1. Midbrain at level of inferior colliculus - Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncle: The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at the level of the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

  1. Tegmentum of upper pons - Motor nucleus of trigeminal nerve: Which controls the muscles of mastication, is indeed located in the pons, specifically in its tegmentum.

 

  1. Medulla at level of motor decussation - Cuneate and Gracilias nucleus: These nuclei are most dorsal and caudal in medulla at the level of pyramidal decussation. The dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway synapse into second order neurons from their perspective dorsal root ganglia neurons at these nuclei.

 

  1. Midbrain at level of superior colliculus - Edinger westphal nucleus: It is associated with the oculomotor nerve and controls the pupillary reflex and lens shape, is located in the midbrain, near the level of the superior colliculus.

 

  1. Tegmentum of lower pons - Facial colliculus: The facial colliculus, which is not actually a nucleus but a surface feature on the floor of the fourth ventricle created by the facial nerve fibers wrapping around the abducens nucleus, is located in the pons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each brainstem division is associated with specific nuclei or structures:

 

  1. The hypoglossal nucleus in the medulla controls tongue muscles;

 

  1. The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus;

 

  1. The motor nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, controlling mastication muscles, is in the tegmentum of the upper pons;

 

  1. The cuneate and gracile nuclei, involved in the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, are in the medulla at the level of motor decussation;

 

  1. The Edinger-Westphal nucleus, linked to the oculomotor nerve for pupillary reflex and lens shape, is near the superior colliculus in the midbrain;

 

  1. The facial colliculus, a structure created by facial nerve fibers around the abducens nucleus, is in the tegmentum of the lower pons.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 74-86

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior Interosseous Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • This is the clinical case of supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • Median nerve and brachial artery are involved in supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of median nerve.

 

 

  • Supra condylar deformity results in gun stock deformity:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand (excluding the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals).
  •  It is involved in the adduction and abduction of fingers, and some aspects of thumb movements, but not primarily responsible for thumb flexion.
  • Injuries to the ulnar nerve typically result in symptoms such as a "claw hand" deformity and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand, not specifically an inability to flex the thumb.

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve:

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve.
  • It primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Damage to this nerve results in an inability to extend the fingers and the wrist (wrist drop), not an inability to flex the thumb.

 

Option D. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half fingers and the associated palm area.
  • It does not play a significant role in motor control of the thumb, particularly in flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior Interosseous Nerve:

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of the median nerve, innervates the flexor pollicis longus, the lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus.
  •  Injury to this nerve leads to deficits in flexion of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, often assessed by the "pinch grip" test where the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign (forming a circle with the thumb and index finger).

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram singh, pg. 165

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of fatigue, dizziness, and syncope, especially during physical activity. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and a systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. An echocardiogram reveals severe aortic stenosis. Right coronary artery origin part was affected. Where does the right coronary artery originate from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior Aortic Sinus

 

Option D:

 

  • Right coronary artery arises from anterior/right aortic sinus.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior Aortic Sinus is located just above the aortic valve. The right coronary artery does not arise from this sinus. Instead, it's typically the non-coronary sinus or occasionally the left coronary artery that is associated with the posterior aortic sinus.

 

Option B. Coronary Sinus is on the posterior aspect of the heart. The right coronary artery is not connected to the coronary sinus as it is an artery, not a vein.

 

Option C. Left Aortic Sinus, also known as the left posterior aortic sinus. This sinus is typically the origin of the left coronary artery. The left coronary artery branches into the left anterior descending artery and the circumflex artery, supplying blood to the left side of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anterior Aortic Sinus, also known as the right anterior aortic sinus, is the correct origin of the right coronary artery.
  • The right coronary artery arises from this sinus and travels down the right side of the heart, supplying blood to the right atrium, right ventricle, part of the left ventricle, the sinoatrial node and the atrioventricular node.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 265

choices.text: C type nerve fibers, being unmyelinated, have a slower conduction velocity compared to AÎ´ fibers, and B type nerve fibers, being myelinated.
C type nerve fibers, although unmyelinated, have a faster conduction velocity than B type nerve fibers due to their smaller diameter.
B type nerve fibers have a slower conduction velocity than C type nerve fibers because they are primarily involved in autonomic functions.
Both B and C type nerve fibers are myelinated, but C type fibers have a faster conduction velocity due to their smaller diameter.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus presents with complaints of numbness and tingling in her feet. She is particularly troubled by these sensations at night. A nerve conduction study is planned to assess the extent of peripheral nerve damage. Understanding the physiology of nerve conduction, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding nerve fiber types and their conduction velocities?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C type nerve fibers, being unmyelinated, have a slower conduction velocity compared to AÎ´ fibers, and B type nerve fibers, being myelinated, conduct at approximately 10 m/s.

 

Option A: C type nerve fibers are unmyelinated and have the slowest conduction velocity among nerve fibers. This results in slower transmission of pain and temperature sensations. B type fibers are myelinated and involved in autonomic nervous system functions, with a conduction velocity around 10 m/s.

 

Different types of nerve fibers are:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: is incorrect as it falsely states that C type fibers conduct faster than B type fibers. C type fibers are slower due to their lack of myelination.

 

Option C is incorrect because it inaccurately states that B type fibers are slower than C type fibers. B type fibers, being myelinated, conduct impulses faster than unmyelinated C type fibers.

 

Option D is incorrect as it wrongly suggests that both C and B type nerve fibers are myelinated and misrepresents the conduction characteristics of C fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question aims to test the candidate's understanding of the characteristics and conduction velocities of different nerve fiber types, particularly in a clinical context of peripheral neuropathy in diabetic patients.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 94

choices.text: Medial Geniculate Body

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a complaint of disrupted sleep patterns, difficulty falling asleep at night, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Upon, further evaluation, it is found that this patient’s sleep-wake cycle is not synchronized with the environmental light-dark cycle. Which hypothalamic nucleus is most likely involved in the regulation of this patient’s circadian rhythms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suprachiasmatic Nucleus

 

Option C: Correct. The Supra-Chiasmatic Nucleus (SCN) is known as the body's "Master Clock." It regulates circadian rhythms, including the sleep-wake cycle, and is directly influenced by environmental light-dark cues received via the retina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. The Para-Ventricular Nucleus of the hypothalamus primarily regulates the autonomic nervous system and the release of hormones from the pituitary gland, but it is not directly involved in regulating circadian rhythms.

 

Option B: Incorrect. The preoptic nucleus plays a key role in thermoregulation and is involved in sleep regulation, but it does not directly control circadian rhythms and synchronization with the light-dark cycle.

 

Option D: Incorrect. The medial geniculate body is part of the thalamus involved in auditory processing and is not directly responsible for circadian rhythm regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to understand the role of the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the regulation of circadian rhythms and its importance in maintaining synchronization with the environmental light-dark cycle.

 

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 278

questions.text: In cardiac diagnostics, clinicians often refer to the LDH isoenzyme ratio as an indicator of myocardial infarction (MI). In a typical healthy adult, the LDH-2 level is higher than LDH-1. A condition where this ratio is reversed, with LDH-1 being higher than LDH-2, is sometimes described in clinical practice. Is the term "flipped pattern" correctly applied to the scenario where LDH-2 is higher than LDH-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False     

 

Explanation

 

Healthy individual has LDH-2 higher than LDH-1. After certain types of myocardial injury, such as an MI, cardiac cells release more LDH-1 than LDH-2, which can lead to LDH-1 becoming higher than LDH-2. This reversal is what's referred to as a "flipped pattern," so the statement LDH-2 >>> LDH-1 being known as a flipped pattern is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests understanding of LDH isoenzyme patterns in normal and pathological states. The five LDH isoenzymes (LDH-1 through LDH-5) consist of different combinations of H (heart) and M (muscle) subunits. LDH-1 (Hâ‚„) predominates in heart tissue, LDH-5 (Mâ‚„) predominates in liver and skeletal muscle, and the others are hybrid forms. The normal serum pattern (LDH-2 > LDH-1) gets reversed in myocardial infarction, creating the "flipped pattern" (LDH-1 > LDH-2). While historically important, LDH isoenzyme analysis has been largely replaced by more specific cardiac markers such as troponin in modern clinical practice.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 69.

questions.text: Among the listed enzymes, which one is NOT typically considered a non-functional enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lipoprotein lipase

 

Explanation:

 

Enzymes found in the plasma can be classified into two types:

 

Non-functional (plasma marker) enzymes:

  • These do not perform any physiological function in plasma.
  • Their presence in serum is typically due to cell damage or turnover.
  • Elevated levels help identify tissue injury or disease.
  • Examples:
    • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) â€“ bone and liver disorders
    • Acid phosphatase â€“ prostate conditions
    • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) â€“ hepatobiliary dysfunction
    • LDH, CK, AST â€“ used as diagnostic markers

 

Functional (plasma active) enzymes:

  • These perform essential metabolic functions within the circulation.
  • They are actively secreted into plasma to carry out physiological roles.

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a classic functional enzyme:

  • It hydrolyzes triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Plays a critical role in lipid metabolism and energy distribution.

 

Other Options:

  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
    â†’ Non-functional enzyme; diagnostic marker for bone and hepatobiliary diseases.
  • Acid phosphatase
    â†’ Non-functional; historically used to detect prostate cancer.
  • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
    â†’ Non-functional; useful in assessing alcoholic liver disease and cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipoprotein lipase is a functional plasma enzyme, directly involved in lipid metabolism.
  • In contrast, non-functional enzymes like ALP, ACP, GGT do not have roles in the plasma but serve as important clinical markers of tissue damage.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 301.
